title: 11 Ways You Can Get Free Internet Access Right Now

steps.title: Visit a library, hospital, or college campus.
steps.content: Visit a library, hospital, or college campus. Even if you're not a current student, most college campuses offer free wireless access to anyone on the premises. The same goes for hospitals, even if you aren't a patient. Most libraries have computers with internet access that anyone can use, but you may also find a library that offers free Wi-Fi. Some libraries/schools have daily use restrictions or content restrictions, so make sure you know what you can and cannot do before using these resources. Look for a Wi-Fi network called "Guest" or "Open" when searching. If a password is required for guests, ask someone at an information desk how to proceed.

steps.title: Visit a chain restaurant, retailer, or hotel that offers free Wi-Fi.
steps.content: Visit a chain restaurant, retailer, or hotel that offers free Wi-Fi. The internet's role in daily life is hard to ignore, which is why many businesses and public buildings offer free Wi-Fi. While there may be a caveat for the Wi-Fi—you may have to buy a drink or a snack or create a membership with the business—the "cost" for the Wi-Fi is usually minor enough that it's worth paying. Some examples of free Wi-Fi locations include the following: Coffee shops (Starbucks, Peet's) Airports (Nearly all airports in the United States and other countries offer free Wi-Fi, although some require payment) Hotels, though some may require payment or a reservation (Hyatt, Best Western, Motel 6, Comfort Inn, Extended Stay America, Walt Disney Resorts) Restaurants (Taco Bell, McDonald's, Dunkin, Einstein Bros, IHOP, Denny's, Krispy Kreme, Panera, Wendy's) Retail Stores (Apple, Office Depot, Lowes, Ikea, Target, Best Buy, Staples, Whole Foods, Safeway) Community centers Truck stops (Love's, Flying J, Petro, TA) Malls (Typically, there will be a free mall-wide Wi-Fi service, and some stores may offer their own)

steps.title: Use WiFi Map to find free hotspots.
steps.content: Use WiFi Map to find free hotspots . WiFi Map is a free crowdsourced website and mobile app that lists free wireless internet access worldwide. Although you'll need internet access to use WiFi Map initially, you can write down the suggested locations and keep them available when you're on the go. Check out https://www.wifimap.io in your web browser, or download the official app (by WiFi Maps LLC) to your Android, iPhone, or iPad. On an iPhone or iPad, open the App Store and search for WiFi Map・eSIM, Internet Finder . Tap the GET button on the app to install it. On an Android, open the Play Store and search for WiFi Map: Internet, eSIM, VPN . Tap the INSTALL button to download the app, and then tap its icon to open it.

steps.title: Ask your cable, DSL, or satellite provider if they offer free hotspots.
steps.content: Ask your cable, DSL, or satellite provider if they offer free hotspots. Many internet companies, including Xfinity, provide free wireless hotspots around major cities for current customers. All you need to do to access them is log in with your account email and password. Most other internet providers that offer free hotspots have Wi-Fi locators on their websites.

steps.title: Install the Instabridge app.
steps.content: Install the Instabridge app. Instabridge, which you can get from the Google Play Store for Android or App Store for iOS, maps free public Wi-Fi hotspots offered by other Instabridge members. Before you head out, search for free internet in locations you visit often, and tap any pin on the map to view and save that Wi-Fi network's password. Then, when you are near that access point, you can connect to it for free internet access. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Use your phone's data plan as a hotspot.
steps.content: Use your phone's data plan as a hotspot. If you have internet access on your phone through a mobile data provider, you may be able to use it to get your computer online as well. This is called "tethering," and some mobile providers allow you to use a certain amount of data for tethering as a part of your plan. See How to Connect to the Internet On Your Laptop Through Your Cell Phone to learn how to set up tethering on your iPhone or Android. [2] X Research source Contact your mobile provider to ask if tethering is included with your plan, and make sure you understand all of the potential charges.

steps.title: See if your school or employer offers free or discounted internet.
steps.content: See if your school or employer offers free or discounted internet. If you're a student, teacher, or employee of a participating company, you may be eligible for free internet access through your school, company, or an affiliated service provider. Even if the service isn't free, discounts may be available to current students and employees.

steps.title: Find free or discounted internet service for low-income households.
steps.content: Find free or discounted internet service for low-income households. Some regions offer free or deeply discounted services for residents who qualify for food stamps, Medicaid/Medicare, or other government resources. If you're in the United States, Lifeline offers free or discounted internet and mobile phone services for qualifying households. To sign up, go to https://www.nyc.gov/assets/bigappleconnect , find your apartment complex, and contact the phone number provided. [4] X Trustworthy Source State of New York Official website for the State of New York Go to source Call your region's information line (211 in many US regions) to ask about free and discounted internet options.

steps.title: Sign up for NetZero or Juno.
steps.content: Sign up for NetZero or Juno. Both NetZero and Juno offer 10 hours of dial-up internet per month at no cost. [5] X Research source If you want a faster connection, both services provide upgrades for $30/month, but only if you use a Windows PC. You will need a phone line and a modem for dial-up internet access. Other internet service providers (ISPs) sometimes offer free hours or trials as well, so keep an eye out for these promotions. If you sign up for a trial, make sure to cancel your account before you are billed for service.

steps.title: Students can sign up for T-Mobile's Project 10Million.
steps.content: Students can sign up for T-Mobile's Project 10Million. This T-Mobile program provides 200 GB of free internet to eligible low-income students. If you qualify, T-Mobile will send you a mobile hotspot you can use to access the internet from anywhere. You (or your child) must be a part of the National School Lunch Program, SNAP, TANF, FPIR, CEP, Medicaid, Head Start, or be a foster, migrant, homeless, or runaway youth to qualify. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Contact your mobile phone provider about internet access.
steps.content: Contact your mobile phone provider about internet access. Some mobile providers, such as Verizon, offer discounted or free home internet service to mobile subscribers. Free offers tend to be limited to low-income subscribers, but you may be able to find a package deal that discounts the internet service to a very, very low cost. [7] X Research source
